contents.p: What do they do, and why are they useful?
Included because heading semantics (hierarchical labels describing sections of content) should align with the title of the page (especially the top-level headings).

As pointed out in WCAG 2.1 (Success Criteria 2.4.10 - Section Headings), not all pages require headings. However, any page with content broken down into sections (covers many pages) should have HTML headings.
Semantic regions such as header, nav, main, footer, aside, and search.

As pointed out on the WebAIM page linked below, every page should have one 'main' element, and most pages should have only one 'header' and one 'footer'. All three of these should be top-level elements (direct children of the 'body' element).

WebAIM also warns against the overuse of nav elements (or the navigation role). Generally a page should have a primary navigation region, and perhaps one or two secondary nav regions. Links in the 'footer' do not necessarily need to be enclosed in a nav element.
More than one region of the same type need unique labels so that users can tell them apart. (See this frequently with the 'navigation' role.)

ul.li: All users benefit from being able to scan the headings on a page and treat them as if they were an outline or table of contents.
Screen reader users rely heavily on navigating among pages based on the page title, and within pages among headings and landmark regions.

li.a: WebAIM: Semantic Structure: Regions, Headings, and Lists

contents.p: Utilize the Firefox Sidebar to display the semantic structure of a web page, including its page title, headings, and landmark regions, for web accessibility evaluation.
Provides keyboard access to landmark regions and headings (h1–h6) on a web page.

ul.li:
Page Structure lists all headings and landmarks on a page. Its purpose is for manual checking of the semantic structure of a page.
Does the page title accurately describe what is found on the page?
Are headings used, and do they properly label the content sections? Are they used in the proper order?
Are landmarks used to identify the important regions on a page?

SkipTo Landmarks & Headings is an assistive technology. It enables easy and efficient navigation with the page to its headings and important landmark regions.
Heading levels displayed are configurable. By default, only h1 through h3 are shown. Through user preferences you can change this to a depth of h2 (minimum) to h6 (maximum depth).
Not all landmarks are shown. The extension will alway list the following landmark roles: 'main', 'search', 'navigation', and 'contentinfo'. You can toggle on or off the display of 'complementary' landmarks ('aside' element).
Improved reliability and responsiveness to page updates and tab changes.
Support for ARIA 1.2 requirements.
Support for ARIA in HTML requirements.
Export evaluation results as CVS or JSON format.
Element details view includes more information about each element.
Removed "HTML4 Legacy Techniques" rule set, only "HTML and ARIA Techniques" ruleset.

contents.p: Page Structure for Firefox is open source software. The code is available at https://github.com/a11y-tools/page-structure.
